div1.p:
Cornelia Kean has been much interest-
ed in reading Gen. Albert E. Truby's book
just published by Paul B. Hoeber Inc-
the Med. Book Dept of Harper & Brothers. N. Y.
entitled Memoir of Walter Reed- The Yellow
Fever Episode- In talking about it and
the courage shown by various people during
the epidemic at Marianao in the Spring
of 1900 I mentioned the following incident
Major Edmunds of the Infantry who was
then on Gen. Fitzhugh Lee's staff, he being
the Comd'g Gen- Dept of Western Cuba,
was living at 27 Gen. Lee Street (formerly
27 Carvajal St.) where I had lived the
year before- Mrs Edmunds and two
young children were with him- He was
taken sick with Yellow Fever on June 12,
1900 and Mrs Edmunds became ill with it the
next day- Capt. Alex. N. Stark was then the
Post Surgeon and was living with his wife
and two small boys Alex and Newton at
quarters at the Post Hospital less than half a
mile away. When he heard of the illness of
both the Edmunds he took their two children
into his family and cared for them until the
recovery of Mrs Edmunds- The Major died about
noon on June 18th and we buried him at 6 p. m.
the same day- Nothing was known of the mosqui-
2
to theory and yellow fever was believed to be
intensely contagious and liable to be brought
into their family by this act, the generosity
and courage shown by the Starks is worthy of
being placed on record- I now regret much
that I did not call General Truby's attention
to it when we were in correspondence about
this fine book- But I failed to note it in
my own diary in those hectic days- It was
from a visit to Edmunds that undoubted-
ly I contracted the disease. I was taken
ill on June 21, 1900-

2. The conditions for the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor
on Feb. 28, 1929 the Act of Congress creating this
Roll on which were to be placed the men
who volunteered to undergo the experiments
necessary to demonstrate the conveyance of the
disease by a certain variety of mosquito was
approved by the President- The members of the
Reed Yellow Fever Board were also placed
on this Roll- To determine what men were
entitled to be named in the Act the Committees
of the Senate and H. R. needed reliable infor-
mation which was furnished by the Sur-
geon General of the Army, then Major Gen-
eral M. W. Ireland- He called certain
officers in conference in his office
to determine what conditions should be
imposed to limit the member of those
who had taken part in this work to the
men whose act definitely contributed to
the discovery- or demonstration- If those who cared for the
sick yellow fever cases were included it
was evident that it would be imposible
to draw any line and this spendid
reward would be given to doctors nurses
and men of the Hospital Corps who had
simply performed their duty, for which
they were engaged- Also there were a
number who in the earlier experiments
offered themselves and were bitten but
without any infection- There was no
official list of these men, as the whole
matter was secret on account of the
military quarantine at Columbia
Barracks, and few of these volunteers
believed that they incurred any danger-
So it was required that only experiments
in which infection with the disease follow-
ed should be counted, as these definitely
contributed to the discovery or demonstration
A man or woman who while nursing the
sick became infected did not prove
anything, that had not been known
for many years. The men who slept in infec
ted bedding were in quite a different
category- Not only did they take chances
which every doctor in America would
have told them were certain to lead to
infection, but the repulsive conditions
of their experiment which lasted three
weeks instead of 3 minutes, tried
their endurance as well as their cou-
rage to the utmost- The contribution
which they made to the experiment
was the fact that they did not
become infected- I have never
understood why Gen. Gorgas paid
so little attention to the vast im-
portance of these experiments-
Altho. Circular no. 5 Hdqrs Dept of Cuba
April 27/1901 eliminating disinfecting
had been issued after approval by the
Surgeon General of the Army Major
Gorgas paid no attention to it until
he had become converted to the
mosquito theory, as the only way, in
August 1901- He then wrote to Reed
telling him that he Gorgas had as Health
officer of Havana discontinued the
disinfection of the personal effects of
persons coming from a locality believe
to be infected- The Public Health & Quaran-
tine Service were slow to accept the
logical conclusions of Reed's demonstra-
tions-
In order to answer questions of Col
Philip S. Hench as to the occurrences
and movements of the persons con-
cerned in the Y. F. Episode of 1900
in Cuba I have looked over my
diary to see their movements during
the latter half of the year-

I was taken ill with y. f. June 21st 1900
I woke in the early morning with headache
backache & fever & went over to the
hospital for examination after letting
Gen. Lee that I was going into the hospital
my attack was well marked with hemorrhage
from the gums but no albuminuria-
I was treated in one of the Small one
room huts south of the Playa R R-
Captain Hepburn who was taken sick
about the same time was in the room
with me and was discharged at the
same time- He had also a mild attack
He also went north to New York on the Ward
Line Str Vigilancia with me on July 3-
We arrived N. Y. on the 7th and having white
certificates from the P. H. & M. H. Service were
passed thru quarantine without delay,
The other non-immune passengers had to
go to Hoffman's Island for 5 days
observation in quarantine- I joined my
family at Morristown N. J. and saw my
little son, two days old, on the afternoon
of July 7- I was still feeling weak
and had a conjunctivitis of my right
eye which came on during the fever-
A disastrous outbreak of yellow fever occurred
at Pinar del Rio some after I was taken
sick and it was not promptly diag-
nosed due to neglect of the Post Surgeon
to follow instructions as to the clinical
examination of blood & urine in fever
cases- It was promptly terminated
by the old and well established pro-
cedure of moving the troops into Camp
only one case occurred after the move.
I sailed from N. Y. to Havana Aug- 9
arriving there Aug 13th at 6 P. M.
I went to Pinar del Rio on Aug- 23 - &
to Guanajay on 28th Returned to Mari-
-anao on Aug. 30- Reed & Truby leave Cuba Aug.
2nd
Went to Havana Sept. 1 with Starks- They went
to U. S. on Sept 3rd with Gen Lee & others on
leave-

Carroll taken ill on Friday Aug 31st & “is quite
ill today Sept 3-” He was much better on 7th
Sept 6- I lunched with Gorgas & went
after to Las Animas Hosp where we saw
some 25 cases of y. f- There are 70 odd
in Havana-

Tuesday Sept 18- Dr. Peter C. Field & Truby-
& Baker & Ladd came on Sedgewich 17th
Sunday 16th my old friend Major Cartwright
sick at Hdqrs- I spent the day with him
& then in eve sent him to y. f. hospital
much against his will- He had gone to
bed night of 15th feeling badly- Temp 104°F
on 18th- Col. Havard & I went on
the Sedgwith on Wedsday 19th to Cienfuegos
on an inspection- We went around the west-
end of Island- We got back to Havana Mon-
day Sept. 24- Found that Major Cartwright
had died the day before (23rd) at 7 a m
Dr- Lazear is very sick but a little
better today 24th. He did Sept 25 at
8 P. M.

Col Sloeum returned from leave Sept 28th
& is appd Acting Chief Q. M. to take Cartwrights
place-

Oct 7th Went with Chief Surg Col Havard to

October, 1900
Matanzas on inspection on Oct-3rd Wed-
At night went on board transport Crook to
see Reed who is returning from Wash-
He is much grieved over Lazear's death
Returned home Friday 5th Saw Reed 6th
He said Carrolls mosquito bit him on 12th day
& X. Y. s on 16th day- Told me the story of a
bite from a mosquito which he thought a
pungers- Reed thinks he is on the Eve
a great discovery-

Reed sailed Oct. 13 to consult the Surg Gen-
I went with him Oct. 12 to see Gen Wood
& explain his need of money & authority
for experiments on men- Wood prom-
ised him both-

Major & Mrs Peterson were buried yesterday Oct. 20
He died of Y. F. 18th & she committed suicide-
Major Dodge Ch. Paymaster has recovered from
his attack of y. f.

Col. Havard has a mild case-
Capt- Page died of it Oct- 25
Louise & children sailed 23rd went to Matan
zas to meet them & went on boad Cook
Sunday mon 28th spent the day with them
& came to Havana with them on her ass. 29th
Starks also on board-
Reed was on board returning from Wash-
Havand goes to U. S. & I become Acting Ch Surg
Nov. 19.

Oct. 15. I issue circular to begin mosquito
warfare in Western Cuba-

Camp Lazear completed Nov, 20
Experiments with fomiles begin " 30
Kissinger bitten by infected mosquitoes Nov 20
Nov. 23. Dec 5- taken sick Dec. 9th
Havana Yellow Fever Board confirms diagnosis
Dec. 16
General Order No. 6 Dept Cuba issued Dec. 21,
Moran taken sick Dec. 25.
Col. Havard returns to Cuba Jan 8 1901

1900
Nov. 15 the Dept of Western Cuba is abolish-
ed- Gen Fitzhugh Lee leaves Cuba on
Nov 18th wife of Major Ladd, Treas of Cuba
taken with y. f. a mild case but well worked
Capt- Cook Q M D died of y. f. Nov. 24
Dec 19 I go with Reed to see Gen Wood
& tell him of the success of experiments
Then we go to breakfast with the Gorgases
Carroll recommended for a Commission as Major
of volunteers

Dec 22. Dinner given by the Cuban
doctors of Havana to Dr Carlos Finlay
to celebrate the confirmation of his mos-
quito theory by Reed's experiments-
Mme Abren at La Quinta Las Delicias
entertained us & the officers of the German
Cruiser Venita - Dec. 27

Jan. 1st I go to see Reed and Moran
who is now convalescent
Jan 8- On Col Havard's return I
turn over his office to him and
ask excuse from other duty until and
of month so as to study for exam for
promotion to Major which is impending
I sailed Wed. Jan 30 via Tampa for
Wash. where arr. Feb, 2nd Finished my
exam Feb. 8- Returned to Havana Feb. 20
1901
I assumed duty as Post Surgeon Columbia Bks
March 9, 1901 & moved to at Hospital 11th
1901-
March 25, 1901 The starks left for duty
in the U. S.

May 23rd I was relieved from duty
as Surgeon at Columbia Bks and
reported to Gen. Leonard Wood the
Military Governor of Cuba as Jefe
de Beneficencia in Charg of all the
the hospitals asylums - eleemosynary
institutions in Cuba- I had spent the
proceeding month in going all over the
Island on trips of inspection with Major
Geeble who had been in Charge of
them-
